title: Primary Hyperparathyroidism with Nephrolithiasis
setup_script: A 55-year-old man presents with recurrent kidney stones and mild hypercalcemia. Serum calcium is 11.5 mg/dL (normal 8.5–10.5), PTH is elevated, and bone density T-score is −2.6. Neck ultrasound shows a 1.5 cm parathyroid adenoma behind the left inferior thyroid pole. How would you proceed?

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about symptoms and history
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient reports recurrent nephrolithiasis and bone pain. No family history of MEN syndromes.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders labs beyond calcium and PTH
dynamic_flow.reply: 24-hour urinary calcium is elevated; vitamin D is normal; renal function is preserved.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident inquires about bone health
dynamic_flow.reply: Bone density scan confirms osteoporosis with T-score −2.6.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about indications for surgery
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient meets criteria due to kidney stones, osteoporosis, and elevated calcium.
Sestamibi scan confirms uptake in the left inferior gland, correlating with ultrasound findings.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about surgical approach
dynamic_flow.reply: Options include focused parathyroidectomy with intraoperative PTH monitoring vs. four-gland exploration. Patient is otherwise healthy and prefers minimally invasive approach.
Vocal cord function is documented as normal on preoperative laryngoscopy.
Focused left inferior parathyroidectomy is performed.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about intraoperative monitoring
dynamic_flow.reply: Intraoperative PTH drops more than 50% from baseline at 10 minutes post-excision.
Pathology confirms a parathyroid adenoma weighing 1.2 grams. No evidence of carcinoma.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about immediate postoperative management
dynamic_flow.reply: Serum calcium is checked every 6 hours; calcium supplementation initiated for mild hypocalcemia symptoms.
Patient monitored for hypocalcemia and hungry bone syndrome. Symptoms improve with supplementation.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about long-term follow-up
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient referred to endocrinology and nephrology for stone prevention, bone health, and periodic calcium monitoring.
Counsel patient on hydration, dietary calcium intake, and need for ongoing monitoring.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident is asked to describe technical details of the operation
dynamic_flow.reply: Please describe your incision, dissection technique to identify the adenoma, handling of surrounding structures (including recurrent laryngeal nerve), and methods used to preserve the remaining parathyroid glands.

critical_decision_points: Identifying indications for surgery based on calcium level, kidney stones, and bone density.
Selecting appropriate localization studies and surgical approach.
Using intraoperative PTH monitoring to confirm excision.
Managing postoperative calcium and recognizing hungry bone syndrome.
Describing operative technique and handling of key anatomical structures.
Educating the patient on long-term follow-up and recurrence monitoring.
